page.title: 01Pentland Skerries
page.content: Pentland Skerries lies at the eastern entrance to the Pentland Firth. The largest of the skeris, Muckle sherry, is included in this area. It is rough moorland about 1 kilometre long and 3/4 kilometre wide, and about 18 metres at its highest point. The island was farmed originally but was abandoned last century. The only visible remains of farming being several stone dykes. The highest point of Muckle Skerry is now the site for the Pentland skerries lighthouse, marking the entrance to the pentland Firth. This is at present still manned by three keepers, but eventually will be made an automatic light. Access to the Skerries is difficult because of the tidal flow through the Pentland Firth, which in places can be 9 knots or more.
